Cobalt (Co)-based catalysts exhibit exceptional versatility in CO2 hydrogenation, yielding valuable fuels and chemicals like methane, methanol, and ethanol. Generally, the Co0–Co2+ synergy plays a vital role in promoting this process, yet a quantifying descriptor remains absent. This study presents a series of CoAl-CO3 2− layered double hydroxide (LDH) derived catalysts synthesized through coprecipitation. By tuning precipitation pH and reduction temperature, various Co-based catalysts with distinct reduction degrees and dispersions were obtained. By introducing the descriptor "fraction of reduced and surface exposed Co (F Co,r,s)", the Co0–Co2+ synergy is effectively quantified for CO2 hydrogenation. The balanced Co0–Co2+ synergy in catalysts yields a moderate F Co,r,s, resulting in high turnover frequencies (TOFs) for CO2 conversion via HCOO intermediate formed at the Co0–Co2+ interfaces. The HCOO species can be hydrogenated to form methane and methanol, as well as coupled with CHx intermediate followed by hydrogenation to form ethanol. Conversely, catalysts with excessively high or low F Co,r,s display poor Co0–Co2+ synergy and consequently lower TOFs. A clear volcano-shaped relationship between F Co,r,s and TOFs for CO2 conversion, methane, methanol, and ethanol formation underscores its significance as a key determinant of Co-based catalysts' CO2 hydrogenation performance. The catalyst with optimized Co0–Co2+ synergy (precipitated at pH 8.5 and reduced at 750 oC) possesses a high CO2 conversion rate of 26.8 mmol gcat −1 h−1 at a low temperature (i.e., 180 oC). Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords CO2 hydrogenation Cobalt Synergy Descriptor Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hydrogenation of CO2 into renewable fuels and chemicals has emerged as a crucial strategy to mitigate CO2 emissions and combat global warming. This process involves the utilization of diverse catalysts to facilitate the reaction between CO2 and H2 gas, yielding a range of valuable products. Depending on the specific catalyst and reaction conditions employed, the products can encompass methane, long-chain alkanes, olefins, methanol, and higher alcohols [1–7]. Notably, Co-based catalysts have demonstrated remarkable versatility in CO2 hydrogenation, being capable of producing methane, C2–4 olefins, methanol, and higher alcohols [4,5,8–13]. The remarkable catalytic versatility of Co-based materials in converting CO2 into diverse products arises from the presence of various active components within the prepared catalysts, including metallic Co (Co0), Co oxide (CoO), and Co carbide (Co2C) [4,5,13–16]. Co0 is known to play a crucial role in H2 dissociation, providing active H species [5,17,18], and Co-based catalysts with a higher proportion of Co0 species generally exhibit superior CO2 conversion rates [19–21]. Additionally, Co0 has been observed to activate CO2 more effectively than CoO [15,21]. Some studies also propose that Co0 displays higher activity in CO2 hydrogenation compared to CoO. For instance, Co0 supported on SiO2, Al2O3, and CeO2 achieved a higher turnover frequency (TOF) or yield for CO2 hydrogenation than its oxide counterpart [15,22]. Nevertheless, there are conflicting findings, with some studies suggesting that CoO may exhibit higher activity than Co0, particularly when supported on TiO2 [15,22]. It is also mentioned that the catalytic behavior of metallic Co-based catalysts primarily involves the direct dissociation pathway, with adsorbed CO as a crucial intermediate [15]. Conversely, CoO-based catalysts predominantly follow the H-assisted pathway, involving carbonate, formate, and formyl species [15]. While the direct dissociation pathway exhibits faster kinetics compared to the H-assisted pathway, the latter appears to be more advantageous for the production of C2+ hydrocarbons [15]. Furthermore, synergetic effects between Co0 and CoO have been also reported. For instance, it has been observed that partially reduced CoO exhibits a synergistic function between CoO and Co0 during the CO2 methanation reaction [21]. In this context, CoO facilitates the moderate binding of CO2, while Co0 provides the necessary electrons for the hydrogenation steps. Consequently, the Co0–CoO synergy results in the highest catalytic activity during CO2 hydrogenation. Moreover, Wang et al. demonstrated that the coexistence of Co0 and CoO promotes the production of *CHx during the formate into acetate conversion via insertion mechanism. Subsequently, acetate undergoes hydrogenation, facilitating the formation of ethanol [10]. Similarly, LaCo1–xGaxO3 perovskite derived Co/La4Ga2O9 catalyst also possess a Co0–Co2+ synergy due to the interaction between Co0 nanoparticles and La4Ga2O9. The synergy contributes to the *CHx formation, promoting ethanol synthesis by CO2 hydrogenation [23]. Despite extensive research on identifying active Co species and understanding their synergy is undergoing, the rational tailoring of the Co-based catalyst's structure to enhance its catalytic activity in CO2 hydrogenation remains challenging. One of the main reasons for this challenge lies in the difficulty of precisely controlling the formation of various catalytically active Co species, which strongly depends on the composition and synthesis conditions of the catalysts. Additionally, another obstacle is the lack of a well-defined descriptor to quantify the synergy between different Co species, hampering the guided design of catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation. Herein, we report the synthesis of a series of catalysts containing Co0 and Co2+ by utilizing a CoAl-CO3 2− LDH precursor through co-precipitation. By carefully controlling the precipitation pH and reduction temperature, Co-based catalysts with varying ratios between Co0 and CoO/CoAl2O4 can be obtained, resulting in diverse catalytic activities for CO2 hydrogenation. Subsequently, we establish a correlation in the form of a volcano-shaped plot between the fraction of reduced and surface-exposed Co atoms and the catalysts’ activity for CO2 hydrogenation. A medium fraction of reduced and surface-exposed Co atoms favors the Co0–Co2+ synergy, promoting CO2 conversion through a HCOO intermediate. This correlation will potentially serve as a valuable guideline for the future design of Co-based catalysts targeted at higher activity for CO2 hydrogenation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of catalysts A series of Co-based catalysts were synthesized through a co-precipitation method [24], followed by calcination in air and subsequent reduction in H2. Initially, solution A, containing 0.06 M Co(NO3)2 and 0.06 M Al(NO3)3, was prepared. Then, solution B, containing 0.12 M Na2CO3 and 0.40 M NaOH, was prepared. Subsequently, solutions A and B were mixed in a beaker placed in an ice bath with stirring to obtain a suspension while maintaining a constant pH (i.e., 8.0, 8.5, 9.0, 9.5). In this research, we chose a Co/Al ratio of 1, which has been shown to enhance the performance of Co-based catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation in previous studies [25]. The resulting suspension was then filtered to isolate the precipitate, which was subsequently washed with deionized water to remove impurities. The obtained precipitate was dried at 100 oC, followed by calcination in air at 400 oC for 3 h, and reduction in H2 for 3 h at temperatures of 450, 550, 650, or 750 oC. The catalysts were labeled as PX-CY-RZ, where P represents pH, C represents calcination, R represents reduction, X represents the pH value for precipitation, Y indicates the calcination temperature, and Z indicates the reduction temperature. If CY or PZ is absent, it signifies that the material was not subjected to calcination or reduction, respectively. 2.2 Characterization of catalysts X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was performed using a SmartLab diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα x-ray source (λ = 1.5406 Å, 40 kV, and 40 mA), and the crystal sizes were calculated by Scherrer equation. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was carried out using a Kratos Axis Supra spectrometer. The binding energies of the spectra were calibrated using the C 1 s peak at 284.8 eV as a reference. N2 physisorption measurements were conducted at 77 K using a Micromeritics 2460 instrument. The contents of Co and Al were quantified using inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) with a Varian 720ES instrument. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of the calcined samples were obtained using a ZEISS Sigma 500 Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of the samples after reduction were acquired using an FEI Talos F200S Field Emission Transmission Electron Microscope. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), H2 temperature-programmed desorption (H2-TPD), and CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) measurements were performed using a VDSorb-9Xi chemisorption analyzer. For H2-TPR measurements, first, the catalysts were subjected to a drying process under Ar (30 mL/min) at 150 oC for 1 h. Subsequently, the system was cooled to 70 oC before being heated to 800 oC (with a heating rate of 10 oC/min) and held at 800 oC for 10 min under a 10% H2/Ar atmosphere with flow rate of 30 mL/min. For H2-TPD, the catalysts were first reduced in H2 for 3 h, followed by cooling down in Ar to 100 oC and maintained at this temperature for 0.5 h. Then, 10% H2/Ar was introduced for H2 adsorption at 100 oC for 1 h. After flushing with 30 mL/min flow of Ar for 1 h, the catalysts were heated to 800 oC (with a heating rate of 10 oC/min) and kept at 800 oC for 50 min to desorb the adsorbed H2. For CO2-TPD, the catalysts were first reduced in H2 at 450–750 oC for 3 h, followed by cooling down in Ar to 50 oC and maintained at this temperature for 1 h. Then, 30 mL/min of 5% CO2/He was introduced for CO2 adsorption at 50 oC for 1 h. After flushing with He for 1 h, the catalysts were heated to 800 oC (with a heating rate of 10 oC/min) and kept at 800 oC for 50 min to desorb the adsorbed CO2. A thermal conductivity detector was used to measure changes in the thermal conductivity of the gas stream for quantification. The reduction degree, dispersion, and fraction of reduced and surface exposed Co were calculated according to Eqs. (1)–(3), (1) RD = n Co , red n Co , tot (2) D = n Co , red , surf n Co , red (3) F Co , r , s = n Co , red , surf n Co , to t where RD, D, and F Co , r , s indicate the reduction degree, dispersion, and fraction of reduced and surface exposed Co, respectively, n Co,tot indicates total molar number of Co in the catalysts, n Co,red indicates the molar number of Co reduced, and n Co,red,surf indicates the number of reduced and surface exposed Co. 2.3 Catalytic tests CO2 hydrogenation was performed in a Teflon-lined 50 mL autoclave (batch reactor with magnetic stirring). Initially, 15 mL of water was introduced into the autoclave, followed by the addition of 50 mg of the reduced catalyst. Subsequently, 1 MPa of CO2 was introduced into the autoclave and purged three times to completely displace air from the reaction mixture. Next, 1 MPa of CO2 was introduced, followed by an additional 3 MPa of H2. The autoclave was then maintained at 180 oC with stirring (350 rpm) for a duration of 1 h. After completion of the reaction, the autoclave was cooled down in an ice bath. The gaseous products were collected using a gas bag and analyzed via an offline gas chromatography (GC) that is Agilent 8890 GC system equipped with a thermal conductivity detector, HayeSep Q columns, and MolSleve 5 A columns. The concentrations of CH4 and CO were determined using the external standard method. The total quantities of CH4 and CO were subsequently calculated based on the ideal gas state equation. Additionally, the liquid product was subjected to analysis using an offline Agilent 8860 GC system featuring a flame ionization detector and an HP-Innowax column. Tetrahydrofuran was used as an internal standard for quantification. Methanol, ethanol, and methane yields and turnover frequencies were calculated using Eqs. (4) and (5), (4) Y i = n i t × m cat , (5) TOF i = n i t × n Co , red , surf , where Y i indicates the yield of Prodcut i (methanol, ethanol, or methane), n i indicates the molar number of Product i, t indicates reaction time, and m cat indicates the mass of catalysts used, TOF i indicates the TOF of Prodcut i, and the TOF of CO2 conversion is the sum of TOF MEOH, TOF ETOH, and TOF CH4. 2.4 Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy measurements The diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) setup involves a Nicolet IS50 spectrometer equipped with a mercury-cadmium-telluride (MCT) detector, accompanied by a Harrick Praying MentisTM diffuse reflectance accessory featuring a high-temperature reaction chamber. The catalysts were first reduced in H2 at 650 oC for 3 h beforehand. Then the reduced catalysts were placed in the chamber, followed by purging with Ar. Subsequently, the chamber was heated to 180 oC under Ar flow, and the pressure in the chamber was increased to 4 MPa. Next, a mixture of CO2/H2 (12.5/37.5 mL/min) was introduced to initiate the hydrogenation reaction, and the temperature was increased to 230 and 280 oC subsequently. DRIFT spectra were recorded continuously using a scan number of 128 and a resolution of 8 cm−1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure and properties of catalysts The effects of precipitation pH and reduction temperature on the structure and properties of the catalysts were studied using a range of analytical techniques, including ICP-OES, N2 physisorption, SEM, TEM, XRD, XPS, H2-TPR, H2-TPD, and CO2-TPD. The study initially focuses on investigating the effects of precipitation pH on the structure and properties of catalysts or catalyst precursors. The composition of the calcined catalysts was analyzed using ICP-OES, and the results are presented in Table 1. The catalysts precipitated at pH values of 8.0, 8.5, 9.0, and 9.5 and calcined at 400 oC exhibit Co content ranging from 6.03 to 6.54 mmolCo/gcat, with a Co/Al molar ratio between 1.04 and 1.14, consistent with the nominal values used during the synthesis. The XRD analysis reveals that all as-precipitated catalysts possesses a CoAl-CO3 2− LDH structure [26], displaying relatively low crystallinity (Fig. S1). The broadened peaks indicated a somewhat amorphous structure. After calcination in air at 400 oC, the CoAl-CO3 2− LDHs transform into a spinel structure, indicating the formation of Co3O4 and/or CoAl2O4 ( Fig. 1) [27,28]. The domain size (i.e., calculated using (131) reflex with a lattice distance of 2.42–2.43 Å) of the calcined catalysts decreases from 58 to 47 Å as the precipitation pH increases from 8.0 to 9.5 (Table 1). The textural properties of the obtained catalysts were investigated using N2 physisorption. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area of the calcined catalysts is found to be similar, ranging from 169 to 188 m2/g. However, the pore volume and pore diameter decreased with increasing co-precipitation pH (Table 1, Fig. S2). The adsorption-desorption isotherms (Fig. S3) for P8-C400, P8.5-C400, and P9-C400 show a H3 type hysteresis loop, indicating the presence of wedge-shaped pores, which are likely composed of aggregates of plate-like particles or layered materials [29]. On the other hand, P9.5-C400 exhibits a H4 type hysteresis loop, suggesting the existence of slit-shaped pores [29]. The plate-like shape of the obtained materials was also supported by SEM results (Fig. S4). Fig. 2a and b display the Co 2p and O 1 s XPS spectra of the calcined catalysts, precipitated under various pH conditions. The Co 2p peaks corresponding to the 1/2 and 2/3 orbitals are clearly evident, and these can be attributed to the presence of low spin Co3+ in the octahedral sites and high spin Co2+ in the tetrahedral sites of the spinel structure of Co3O4 and CoAl2O4, along with their satellite peaks [30]. The O 1 s XPS spectrum indicates the presence of metal oxide (M-O), O vacancies (Ov), and surface OH species [31]. To precisely determine the Co2+ fraction and the Ov/M-O ratio in the catalysts, deconvolution of the obtained XPS spectra was conducted. In Fig. 2c, it is evident that as the co-precipitation pH increases, the Co2+ fraction initially increases, reaching a maximum of 77% at a pH of 8.5, and then decreases with further increase in pH. Concurrently, the Ov/M-O ratio also rises with increasing pH, indicating a higher concentration of O vacancies on the catalyst's surface. This observation is consistent with the decreasing crystalline size obtained from the XRD study, suggesting that catalysts with smaller crystallites possess a higher density of O vacancies on their surfaces [32]. Reducibility of the calcined catalysts prepared under various pH values was further studied by H2 TPR. As shown in Fig. 3, all the TPR profiles show two sets of peaks, the α and β peaks at two temperature regions. The low-temperature α peak is attributed to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO and then to Co0 (Co3O4 + 4 H2 → Co0 + H2O), while the high-temperature β peak is attributed to the reduction of CoAl2O4 to Co0 (CoAl2O4 + H2 → Co0 + Al2O3 + H2O) [33]. It is interesting that the β peak temperature follows the order of P8.5-C400 > P9-C400 > P8-C400 ≈ P9.5-C400, suggesting that a stronger interaction between Co and Al exists in P8.5-C400. An analysis of the H2 consumption ratio of the β peak/α peak indicates a slight increase from 3.25 to 3.55 with rising precipitation pH from 8 to 9.5. Besides, it is found that an elevated Co/Al ratio is associated with a higher β peak/α peak ratio. This suggests that an increased amount of Co incorporated into the catalyst under elevated precipitation pH leads to a greater presence of strongly interacted Co. All the calcined catalysts were first reduced at 650 oC in H2, and the P8.5-C400 catalyst was also reduced at 450 oC, 550 oC, and 750 oC. XRD patterns of the reduced catalysts (Figs. S5 and 6) confirm the formation of metallic Co upon reduction under H2 flow. However, complete reduction of CoAl2O4 is not achieved under the applied reduction conditions, consistent with the H2 TPR results, which indicate incomplete reduction profile up to 750 oC. However, the reduction degrees of catalysts under different conditions were calculated using the obtained H2 TPR profiles according to Eq. (1). The total molar number of Co in the catalysts (n Co,tot) was determined based on the amount of Co reduced at 800 oC, while the molar number of Co reduced (n Co,red) was calculated based on the reduction amount at specific temperatures. The reduction degrees of the catalysts are summarized in Table S1. Notably, for catalysts precipitated at various pH values and reduced at 650 oC, the reduction degree decreases linearly with increasing Co2+ fraction calculated by XPS ( Fig. 4a). Besides, for catalysts precipitated at pH 8.5 and reduced at various temperatures, the reduction degree increases exponentially with higher reduction temperatures (Fig. 4b). Thus, by customizing the co-precipitation pH and reduction temperature, catalysts with a wide range of reduction degrees can be obtained for further investigation. Furthermore, H2 activation ability of the reduced catalysts was studied through H2-TPD analysis. H2-TPD profiles of the catalysts co-precipitated at different pH and reduced at 650 oC showed two sets of peaks. The peaks observed at low temperature (∼200 oC) and high temperature (∼800 oC) are attributed to the weakly-binding and strongly-binding H species ( Fig. 5a), respectively [34]. Generally, H species are adsorbed on different adsorption sites such as metallic Co sites (weakly binding H species) and metal-metal oxide interfacial sites (strongly binding H species) [35]. Besides, H2-TPD profiles of the catalysts co-precipitated at pH 8.5 and reduced at 650 and 750 oC also display both low and high-temperature peaks (Fig. 5b). However, the catalysts reduced at lower temperatures (i.e., 450 and 550 oC) exhibit additional medium-temperature desorption peaks at around ∼300 and ∼500 oC, indicating the presence of medium-strongly adsorbed H. This suggests the generation of new metal-metal oxide interfaces by the employed reduction process. Moreover, it is observed that the catalysts reduced at 450 and 550 oC had significantly lower levels of strongly adsorbed H compared to those reduced at 650 oC and 750 oC. The H2-TPD results were used to quantify the Co dispersion based on Eq. (2) (Table S2). Then, the obtained dispersion is further correlated with the reduction degree ( Fig. 6). The data demonstrate a linear decrease in dispersion with an increasing reduction degree. This decrease is attributed to sintering at a higher reduction degree, resulting in larger Co0 particles and subsequently lower dispersion [36]. Consequently, the H adsorption capacity follows a volcano-shaped trend with respect to the reduction degree. The H adsorption capacity first increases with increasing reduction degree, reaching a maximum of 335 umolH/gcat at a reduction degree of 61%. However, further increases in the reduction degree lead to a decrease in the H adsorption capacity. This phenomenon is explained by the fact that at low reduction degrees, the Co0 particles are small, but only a small amount of Co0 was present. Conversely, at high reduction degrees, a significant amount of Co0 exists, but the Co0 particles are large. Both scenarios result in a lower H adsorption capacity. On the contrary, the catalysts with a medium reduction degree exhibit the highest H adsorption capacity since they possess both a high Co0 content and relatively smaller size Co0 particles. The capability of the reduced catalysts to initiate CO2 activation was investigated using CO2-TPD analysis. The catalysts were co-precipitated under varying pH conditions and subsequently reduced at different temperatures, leading to the occurrence of two distinct sets of peaks within the CO2-TPD profiles ( Fig. 7). Notably, a volcano-shaped correlation between the capacity for H adsorption and the capacity for CO2 adsorption is also identified ( Fig. 8). Initially, as the CO2 adsorption capacity increases, the H adsorption capacity rises, reaching a peak before gradually declining with further increments in CO2 adsorption. This phenomenon suggests that, even with a comparable or analogous extent of exposed Co0 surface, there can be substantial variations in CO2 adsorption capacity. For instance, in the case of P8.5-C400-R400 and P8.5-C400-R750, their H adsorption capacities stand at 0.25 and 0.38 mmolH/gcat, respectively. However, their respective CO2 adsorption capacities differ significantly, with values of 0.85 and 0.32 mmolCO2/gcat. This significant difference in CO2 adsorption capacity can be attributed to disparities in the composition and quantity of surface Co oxide species. Among catalysts featuring equivalent H capacities, discrepancies in the types and proportions of Co oxide species might lead to variations in CO2 adsorption capacity. 3.2 Catalytic performance and reaction mechanism of catalysts The catalytic activity of the catalysts was assessed for CO2 hydrogenation in a batch reactor using water as a solvent. Fig. 9 illustrates the results of CO2 hydrogenation over the prepared catalysts at 180 oC and 4 MPa initial pressure, showing the formation of methane, methanol, and ethanol as the products. For catalysts synthesized at various pH values and reduced at 650 oC, the STY for all the three products initially increases and then decreases with increasing pH (Fig. 4a). The highest STY values for alcohols and methane are achieved at co-precipitation pH of 8.5 (358 µmolMEOH/gcat/h, 71 µmolETOH/gcat/h) and 9 (26,756 µmolCH4/gcat/h), respectively. Additionally, the CO2 conversion rate follows a similar trend, reaching its maximum of 27131 µmolCO2/gcat/h at a co-precipitation pH of 9. The alcohol/methane ratio (C based) and ethanol/methanol ratio (C based) also exhibit the same pattern, with the highest value of 0.016 at pH 8.5 and 0.208 at pH 9.0, respectively. On the other hand, when examining catalysts reduced at different temperatures, the methane STY and CO2 conversion rate display a monotonic increase with rising reduction temperature, reaching their peak at 26,373 µmolCH4/gcat/h and 26,767 µmolCO2/gcat/h, respectively, at a reduction temperature of 750 oC. However, the methanol and ethanol STY exhibit different behavior, increasing up to a maximum over the P8.5-C400-R650 catalyst and then decreasing with further increasing reduction temperature. The trends for the alcohol/methane ratio (C based) and ethanol/methanol ratio (C based) follow a similar pattern, reaching their respective maxima of 0.017 and 0.204 at a reduction temperature of 550 oC. Furthermore, we have compared the results obtained in this study with state-of-the-art Co-based catalysts ( Fig. 10, Table S3). To ensure a fair comparison, only catalytic performance tested in an autoclave is considered. The analysis demonstrates that the catalysts developed in this study exhibit a notably higher CO2 conversion rate. The methane STY, methanol, and ethanol exhibit a strong correlation with each other. As depicted in Fig. 11, the ethanol STY shows a linear increase with rising methanol STY. Moreover, an increase in methane STY leads to an initial rise in methanol and ethanol yields, but they subsequently decline when the methane STY reaches excessively higher. These observations suggest a shared intermediate in the formation pathways of methane, methanol, and ethanol. To gain a deeper understanding of the mechanistic aspects of CoAl-CO3 2− LDH-derived catalysts, we conducted in situ DRIFTS experiments to investigate CO2 hydrogenation over the P8.5-C400-R650 catalyst. The experiments were carried out at temperatures ranging from 180 to 280 oC under 3 MPa H2 and 1 MPa CO2, and the time on stream in situ DRIFTS spectra (180–280 oC) and in situ DRIFTS spectrum at 280 oC are presented in Fig. 12 a and b. At a temperature of 180 oC, adsorbed CO2 (3596, 3729, 3700, 2310, 2328 cm−1) [41–44] and CO (2077, 2128, 1933 cm−1) [45–47] species were observed on the catalyst’s surface. As the temperature increases, *HCOO (2886, 2888, 1372, 1435 cm−1) [48–51] species emerged. With further temperature escalation, absorption bands associated with CH4 (3014, 1305 cm−1) [52,53], *CH3COO (1456, 1436, 1418, 1542 cm−1) [54–57], *CH3CH2O (1473 cm−1) [58], and *CH3O (2821, 1032, 1056 cm−1cm−1) [59–61] became apparent. Furthermore, the presence of CH4, *CH3CH2O, and *CH3O species concurrently with an increase in *HCOO intensity suggests *HCOO’s significance as a crucial intermediate during CO2 hydrogenation over CoAl-CO3 2−-derived catalysts. Based on the literature, the *HCOO intermediate can undergo hydrogenation to CH3OH or CH4 ( Fig. 13c) [62,63]. Moreover, a coupling reaction between *CHx and *HCOO followed by hydrogenation, can lead to the formation of ethoxy species and ethanol (Fig. 13c) [10]. The formation of CH4, methanol, and ethanol appears to be closely interconnected, indicating that these products may all arise from an *HCOO intermediate. In general, the metal-metal oxide interface has been suggested to facilitate the formation of *HCOO and its subsequent hydrogenation [64]. Thus, the Co0 and CoO/CoAl2O4 synergy is believed to be of great importance for CO2 hydrogenation over CoAl-CO3 2− LDH derived catalysts. 3.3 Structure-activity correlation To further elucidate the effects of the Co0 and CoO/CoAl2O4 synergy on CO2 hydrogenation over CoAl-CO3 2− LDH derived catalysts, the turnover frequencies (TOFs) were calculated according to Eq. (4) (i.e., based on the number of surface Co sites obtained by H2-TPD). Subsequently, the TOFs of the catalysts were correlated with the reduction degree (RD), dispersion (D), and the fraction of reduced and surface-exposed Co (F Co,r,s), the ratio of reduced Co atoms on the catalyst surface to the total Co atoms in the catalyst. Unfortunately, the TOFs for CO2 conversion, methane formation, methanol formation, and ethanol formation do not show a significant correlation with the reduction degree (Fig. S7) or dispersion (Fig. S8) of the catalysts. However, the fraction of reduced and surface-exposed Co exhibited a strong correlation with the TOFs, revealing a volcano-shaped trend (Fig. 13). As the F Co,r,s increases from 5% to 8%, the TOF increases first, reaching a maximum, and then starts to decrease with further increases in F Co,r,s. When the F Co,r,s exceeds 10%, the TOFs begin to fluctuate slightly. These results indicate that F Co,r,s serves as a suitable indicator for predicting the TOFs for CO2 conversion to methane, methanol, and ethanol, owing to its ability to describe the synergy between Co0 and CoO/CoAl2O4 sites. A moderate value of F Co,r,s suggests a favorable synergy between Co0 and CoO/CoAl2O4 sites, which promotes CO2 conversion through the HCOO intermediate. However, the reduction degree provides information on the Co0/Co2+ ratio in the catalysts but does not account for the availability of Co0 on the surface. Conversely, the dispersion indicates surface availability but does not encompass information on the Co0/Co2+ ratio. Consequently, neither the reduction degree nor the dispersion proves to be a suitable descriptor for the observed catalytic behavior. Catalysts positioned on the left branch of the TOFs-F Co,r,s plot, such as P8.0-C400-R400, exhibit a low reduction degree with high dispersion, resulting in a limited fraction of reduced and surface-exposed Co (5%). This is due to insufficient synergy between Co0 and Co2+ arising from the scarcity of Co0 sites ( Fig. 14a top panel and Fig. 14b). On the other hand, catalysts located on the right branch of the TOFs- F Co,r,s plot, like P8.5-C400-R650, display both a medium reduction degree and dispersion, leading to a higher fraction of reduced and surface-exposed Co (15%). However, there is still inadequate synergy between Co0 and Co2+ due to the deficiency of Co2+ sites (Fig. 14a bottom panel and Fig. 14c). These cases result in low TOFs. For catalysts situated in the middle of the TOFs- F Co,r,s plot, such as P8.5-C400-R750 possess a high reduction degree but low dispersion leading to a medium fraction of reduced and surface-exposed Co (10%). This configuration achieves an efficient synergy between Co0 and Co2+, promoting the conversion of CO2 through an HCOO intermediate (Fig. 14a middle panel and Fig. 14c). Consequently, the highest TOFs are obtained. 4 Conclusion Co-based catalysts demonstrate remarkable versatility in CO2 hydrogenation, leading to the formation of high-value-added products, including methane, methanol, and ethanol. The synergy between Co0 and Co2+ plays a pivotal role in promoting CO2 hydrogenation, making it crucial to quantify its effects on the catalysts' activity. However, relying solely on the reduction degree and dispersion as descriptors is inadequate to quantify the impact of Co0/Co2+ synergy on the CO2 hydrogenation activity of CoAl-CO3 2− LDH derived Co-based catalysts. Therefore, to overcome this limitation, the concept of fraction of reduced and surface-exposed Co (F Co,r,s) which results from the product of reduction degree and dispersion is introduced in this study,. Accordingly, F Co,r,s proves to be a suitable descriptor for CO2 hydrogenation over LDH derived Co-based catalysts. A catalyst with an efficient synergy between Co0 and Co2+ exhibits a medium F Co,r,s, leading to high TOFs for CO2 conversion through HCOO intermediate. Conversely, catalysts with excessively high or low F Co,r,s show insufficient Co0–Co2+ synergy, resulting in low TOFs. Consequently, the TOFs for CO2 conversion, methane formation, methanol formation, and ethanol formation exhibit a volcano-shaped correlation with F Co,r,s, indicating its significance as a determining factor in CO2 hydrogenation activity of CoAl-CO3 2− LDH derived Co-based catalysts. At a low temperature of 180 oC, the catalyst with an optimized Co0–Co2+ synergy (formed by precipitation at pH 8.5 and reduction at 750 oC) can convert CO2 at a high rate of 26.8 mmol gcat −1 h−1. coredata.dc:description: Cobalt (Co)-based catalysts exhibit exceptional versatility in CO2 hydrogenation, yielding valuable fuels and chemicals like methane, methanol, and ethanol. Generally, the Co0–Co2+ synergy plays a vital role in promoting this process, yet a quantifying descriptor remains absent. This study presents a series of CoAl-CO3 2− layered double hydroxide (LDH) derived catalysts synthesized through coprecipitation. By tuning precipitation pH and reduction temperature, various Co-based catalysts with distinct reduction degrees and dispersions were obtained. By introducing the descriptor "fraction of reduced and surface exposed Co (F Co,r,s)", the Co0–Co2+ synergy is effectively quantified for CO2 hydrogenation. The balanced Co0–Co2+ synergy in catalysts yields a moderate F Co,r,s, resulting in high turnover frequencies (TOFs) for CO2 conversion via HCOO intermediate formed at the Co0–Co2+ interfaces. The HCOO species can be hydrogenated to form methane and methanol, as well as coupled with CHx intermediate followed by hydrogenation to form ethanol. Conversely, catalysts with excessively high or low F Co,r,s display poor Co0–Co2+ synergy and consequently lower TOFs. A clear volcano-shaped relationship between F Co,r,s and TOFs for CO2 conversion, methane, methanol, and ethanol formation underscores its significance as a key determinant of Co-based catalysts' CO2 hydrogenation performance. The catalyst with optimized Co0–Co2+ synergy (precipitated at pH 8.5 and reduced at 750 oC) possesses a high CO2 conversion rate of 26.8 mmol gcat −1 h−1 at a low temperature (i.e., 180 oC).
coredata.dc:title: Synergy of Co0-Co2+ in cobalt-based catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation: Quantifying via reduced and exposed atoms fraction
